And not just any law, but it specifically uses the word *Torah*. And less than one chapter earlier leading up to this statement God insists that he never asked for animal sacrifices (Warning: this is blatantly changed in most English editions). Well turn to any one of the first five books of the Bible and in that book alone "God" is found demanding various animal sacrifices reminiscent of pagan practices (especially the "savory aroma" part). Sometimes as atonement for the pettiest of offenses, very often for things that aren't even the fault of the person, and also to gain his favor just like a pagan god. And we know the people in the Old Testament struggled immensely with paganism and idolatry, and we find God complaining about "meaningless sacrifices" multiple times throughout the prophets. From this evidence alone we can confirm Jeremiah 8:8.

In other places God and his followers often break the laws of the Torah. In some of the older stories it's clear that no one knew some of them existed. Much of Jesus's ministry involved being judged for breaking fake laws that the Jewish religion made up.

Your proof-texts are easily explained. Ezra is almost certainly the main scribe who redacted the Old Testament into its modern form, so of course he's going to put a lot of emphasis on the book, because he himself wrote half of it. One of his main complaints was that people were polluting the "holy race" with goyim and Samaritan races, which doesn't exactly help his case. Jesus himself was of the Samaritan race, being descended from the Davidic lineage.

Daniel merely references something from the law given by Moses. That's all he does. He does not contradict Jeremiah, unless there's nothing authentic left in the law according to Moses.

Matthew 5 has the only quote from Jesus that might actually be disputing Jeremiah. However given that it literally contradicts the very sermon it's part of on nearly every point, let alone all the other times Jesus denounces the supposed law, and isn't attested anywhere else except a one-liner in Luke that seems edited in and is in an entirely different spot...this is probably another example of a forgery.

In Matthew 12 Jesus actually agrees with me. Jesus explicitly gives the Pharisees an example of a law that David did right by violating, according to their own scriptures. Thus this law is either a forgery, not all-binding, or misinterpreted. Either way, sola scriptura falls apart.

Mark 10:19 I think you got the verse number wrong.

Another common proof-text which you did not list but is very common is when God's word is described as "pure" or something similar. But when actually read in context it becomes clear that it's speaking of God's faithfulness to his word (trustworthiness), not the accuracy of written scriptures copied over several millenia.

> "However given that it literally contradicts the very sermon it's part of on nearly every point, let alone all the other times Jesus denounces the supposed law" How so?

The whole format of the sermon (and basically his entire ministry) for one: "You have heard it said...but I say to you do not do that, but do this instead". Almost every time he says that he's quoting an Old Testament law and condemning it.

There are also times when God is specifically said to not delight in sacrifices and burnt offerings (especially Psalm 50). And the places that claim he does give a completely outlandish reason such as "it's a savory aroma" which reeks of paganism and prosperity gospel nonsense. The only instances in favor of sacrifices that might be authentic are as personal devotions and probably at least partially metaphorical; not as a sin atonement, as the Torah specifically requires, in fact they condemn that which you said yourself, which is yet another contradiction.

If we do a critical analysis on several Old Testament passages we can see that Jeremiah is correct that the commands for sacrifice were added later. Let's take a look at Leviticus 19 for example:

> When you sacrifice a fellowship offering to the Lord, sacrifice it in such a way that it will be accepted on your behalf. It shall be eaten on the day you sacrifice it or on the next day; anything left over until the third day must be burned up. If any of it is eaten on the third day, it is impure and will not be accepted. Whoever eats it will be held responsible because they have desecrated what is holy to the Lord; they must be cut off from their people.

> If a man sleeps with a female slave who is promised to another man but who has not been ransomed or given her freedom, there must be due punishment. Yet they are not to be put to death, because she had not been freed. The man, however, must bring a ram to the entrance to the tent of meeting for a guilt offering to the Lord. With the ram of the guilt offering the priest is to make atonement for him before the Lord for the sin he has committed, and his sin will be forgiven.

Fair enough; but take a look at the rest of the chapter and you'll notice that it's written in a completely different style. And it's in 1st person, which makes sense, whereas these two are in 3rd person. This pretty much proves them as later additions to the original, and it's entirely consistent with Jeremiah.

> Unless we find an OT law about picking and eating grain on the Sabbath, this is Jesus calling the Teachers out on condemning due to manmade traditions(Mark 7:1-9). To get the point across, he acknowledges that David, a man they held in high regard, did not follow their tradition. Along with this, we see many references Jesus gave to the OT, though he does not once put it under the level of the authoritative Word of God.

According to the Numbers, Moses had someone *brutally stoned* for merely gathering sticks on the Sabbath. And yet Jesus's group was working in the field on the Sabbath. And he said, "Man was not made for the Sabbath, but the Sabbath for man". This alone is a major contradiction. The Pharisees were following the prescription just as it was written in their time. David did not follow the tradition either, because it was wrong. But you will find it right there in the Torah. The only logical conclusion is that it has been tampered with. When you try to reconcile so many contradicting ideas you end up with things like Marcionism, or like most of modern Christendom picking and choosing the parts that align with the preferred theology and ignoring those that don't. The typical excuse for doing this is called dispensationalism, where Jesus apparently "fulfilled the law, well at least the parts we don't like, we'll still keep the ones we like to judge others for" which there is no evidence of whatsoever, and if it were true then why does Jesus rebuke people for not following the supposed "new way" *pre*-Atonement?

And the most fundamental problem is that there is ZERO evidence of God ever sanctioning "The Bible". He did not drop it out of the sky one day, and he did not ever say it was protected from error. It was put together by *humans*, copied over the millenia by *humans*, and made into a replacement for the spirit by *humans*. Jesus could not have even read "The Bible" because it didn't exist until the Roman church compiled it *3 and 1/2 centuries later*. And why did they do it? Not because God told them to, but because Marcion did it, and they wanted to have a counter-canon. Even after this "The Bible" in its modern form, as you know it today, would not exist until after the Reformation! Claiming the Bible as the authority is just as rooted in human tradition as those who say only the KJV 1611 is right. You only believe so because other people told you so.

The whole format of the sermon (and basically his entire ministry) for one: "You have heard it said...but I say to you do not do that, but do this instead". Almost every time he says that he's quoting an Old Testament law and condemning it.

There are also times when God is specifically said to not delight in sacrifices and burnt offerings (especially Psalm 50). And the places that claim he does give a completely outlandish reason such as "it's a savory aroma" which reeks of paganism and prosperity gospel nonsense. The only instances in favor of sacrifices that might be authentic are as personal devotions and probably at least partially metaphorical; not as a sin atonement, as the Torah specifically requires, in fact they condemn that which you said yourself, which is yet another contradiction.

If we do a critical analysis on several Old Testament passages we can see that Jeremiah is correct that the commands for sacrifice were added later. Let's take a look at Leviticus 19 for example:

When you sacrifice a fellowship offering to the Lord, sacrifice it in such a way that it will be accepted on your behalf. It shall be eaten on the day you sacrifice it or on the next day; anything left over until the third day must be burned up. If any of it is eaten on the third day, it is impure and will not be accepted. Whoever eats it will be held responsible because they have desecrated what is holy to the Lord; they must be cut off from their people.

If a man sleeps with a female slave who is promised to another man but who has not been ransomed or given her freedom, there must be due punishment. Yet they are not to be put to death, because she had not been freed. The man, however, must bring a ram to the entrance to the tent of meeting for a guilt offering to the Lord. With the ram of the guilt offering the priest is to make atonement for him before the Lord for the sin he has committed, and his sin will be forgiven.

Fair enough; but take a look at the rest of the chapter and you'll notice that it's written in a completely different style. And it's in 1st person, which makes sense, whereas these two are in 3rd person. This pretty much proves them as later additions to the original, and it's entirely consistent with Jeremiah.

Unless we find an OT law about picking and eating grain on the Sabbath, this is Jesus calling the Teachers out on condemning due to manmade traditions(Mark 7:1-9). To get the point across, he acknowledges that David, a man they held in high regard, did not follow their tradition. Along with this, we see many references Jesus gave to the OT, though he does not once put it under the level of the authoritative Word of God.

According to the Numbers, Moses had someone brutally stoned for merely gathering sticks on the Sabbath. And yet Jesus's group was working in the field on the Sabbath. And he said, "Man was not made for the Sabbath, but the Sabbath for man". This alone is a major contradiction. The Pharisees were following the prescription just as it was written in their time. David did not follow the tradition either, because it was wrong. But you will find it right there in the Torah. The only logical conclusion is that it has been tampered with. When you try to reconcile so many contradicting ideas you end up with things like Marcionism, or like most of modern Christendom picking and choosing the parts that align with the preferred theology and ignoring those that don't. The typical excuse for doing this is called dispensationalism, where Jesus apparently "fulfilled the law, well at least the parts we don't like, we'll still keep the ones we like to judge others for" which there is no evidence of whatsoever, and if it were true then why does Jesus rebuke people for not following the supposed "new way" pre-Atonement?

And the most fundamental problem is that there is ZERO evidence of God ever sanctioning "The Bible". He did not drop it out of the sky one day, and he did not ever say it was protected from error. It was put together by humans, copied over the millenia by humans, and made into a replacement for the spirit by humans. Jesus could not have even read "The Bible" because it didn't exist until the Roman church compiled it 3 and 1/2 centuries later. And why did they do it? Not because God told them to, but because Marcion did it, and they wanted to have a counter-canon. Even after this "The Bible" in its modern form, as you know it today, would not exist until after the Reformation! Claiming the Bible as the authority is just as rooted in human tradition as those who say only the KJV 1611 is right. You only believe so because other people told you so.

“While the people of Israel were in the wilderness, they found a man gathering sticks on the Sabbath day. And those who found him gathering sticks brought him to Moses and Aaron and to all the congregation. They put him in custody, because it had not been made clear what should be done to him. And the Lord said to Moses, “The man shall be put to death; all the congregation shall stone him with stones outside the camp.” And all the congregation brought him outside the camp and stoned him to death with stones, as the Lord commanded Moses.”

The death penalty for violating the sabbath was originally set in Exodus 31:14,
“You shall keep the Sabbath, because it is holy for you. Everyone who profanes it shall be put to death. Whoever does any work on it, that soul shall be cut off from among his people.”

Granted, this could be what led the Pharisees into condemning picking up any item on the sabbath. However, the command for the Sabbath was not to work, and we can logically assume:

1. The man was not gathering sticks for no reason.
2. The man was not gathering sticks to prepare an offering, which is permitted in Numbers 28:9, and confirmed by Jesus in Matthew 12, and would ironically be considered to “profane” the sabbath by the Pharisees(“Or have you not read in the Law how on the Sabbath the priests in the temple profane the Sabbath and are guiltless?”)

The most rational conclusion would be that this man was gathering sticks in a work effort involving sticks, thereby deserving of his penalty. However, “work” does not mean getting out of bed in the morning, nor does it mean lifting up food to eat, such as Jesus were.

> "Man was not made for the Sabbath, but the Sabbath for man". This alone is a major contradiction. 

No? It’s a plainly true statement. Jesus acknowledges that Man was created, then the Sabbath was created as a day to cease working, in remembrance of God ceasing the creation of the universe on the seventh day. This is contradictory to the Pharisees’ idea that Man cannot be healed on the Sabbath, despite it not being work. It’s only a “major contradiction” if you distort the idea of the Sabbath.

> The Pharisees were following the prescription just as it was written in their time. 
No. We see, by the Matthew 12 example, that they followed a misinterpretation of the sabbath.

> When you try to reconcile so many contradicting ideas you end up with things like Marcionism, or like most of modern Christendom picking and choosing the parts that align with the preferred theology and ignoring those that don't.

When you try to reconcile all contradictory ideas, it would end up with things like Marcionism. If we instead review each idea and it’s individual merit, while accepting that, upon review, most interpretations simply don’t hold water, such as God condemning animal sacrifice, we do not end up with things like Marcionism. If we were to have two historical accounts,
John entered the code 3815 to the safe at 11:00 pm. It opened. He closed it.
John entered the code 2815 to the safe at 11:03 pm. It didn’t open.

Interpretations:
“It was the wrong code.”
“The safe is racist.”
“The first historical account is fake.”
“The safe isn’t real.”
“They are different Johns”

If I were to say, “Alright, the safe is a racist and nonexistant. The first account is fake, and between the first and second account are different Johns. Also, it was the wrong code,” I wouldn’t be taken seriously.
If I were to say, “Alright, the safe can’t be racist and nonexistant at the same time, the first historical account is fake,” I could be taken even less seriously. 
With the information we have, we can say “It was the wrong code,” is the interpretation we should follow.

> The typical excuse for doing this is called dispensationalism, where Jesus apparently "fulfilled the law, well at least the parts we don't like, we'll still keep the ones we like to judge others for" which there is no evidence of whatsoever.

“No evidence whatsoever” is flippantly incorrect, but you can disprove the evidence, such as attempted with sacrifice prior.

> If it were true then why does Jesus rebuke people for not following the supposed "new way" pre-Atonement?

I’m not sure what you’re saying here. What “new way?”

> “The whole format of the sermon (and basically his entire ministry) for one: "You have heard it said...but I say to you do not do that, but do this instead". Almost every time he says that he's quoting an Old Testament law and condemning it.”

The quotes in question will be Matthew 5:21, 27, 31, 33, 38, and 43.

“You have heard that it was said to those of old, ‘You shall not murder; and whoever murders will be liable to judgment.’ But I say to you that everyone who is angry with his brother will be liable to judgment; whoever insults his brother will be liable to the council; and whoever says, ‘You fool!’ will be liable to the hell of fire. So if you are offering your gift at the altar and there remember that your brother has something against you, leave your gift there before the altar and go. First be reconciled to your brother, and then come and offer your gift.”

We can reason that Jesus does not wish to abolish the command “You shall not murder,” as either side of the argument contains to records of God ruling murder acceptable, nor does there exist record of God opposed to judgment for murder. Jesus does not reject that God commanded against murder, but it is in His power to evolve the command. Though it was not yet revealed in the Old Testament due to the hard hearts of man, Jesus is enforcing the command against murder to it’s roots, malice towards one’s brother. In mentioning the established command, he demonstrates the base for his enforcement on the spiritual grounds of non-love towards a fellow Man. Though the OT command allowed some flexibility in this regard, Jesus stiffened the command, as it would now be efficient in causing more good in the world as those with softer hearts can now understand.

Could be some new proposed scientific idea like the theory of evolution, which some atheists cite as causing them to lose faith

Could be a technological development that makes them care about God less (like high quality virtual reality that directly connects to the brain or something and gives a new experience of what's possible for humans)

Could be some new finding of ancient writings which creates doubts about Christianity, like people who found "Dead Sea Scrolls" and talk about "The Gospel of Thomas" contradicting Christian teachings or something

I don't believe anything will be found that disproves Christianity, but something will probably arise that challenges the faith of people
